newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - July 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - July 29.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

The Transport Action Group has called on the Australian Securities Commission to postpone the Infrastructure Trust of Australia's investment in the proposed Eastern Distributor tollway in Sydney. The Transport Action Group which is opposed to the tollways construction argues that a independent assessment of likely traffic flows should be completed before the project proceeds any further. Page 17.

Australian company Hundson Conway has withdrawn from the Lend Lease consortium overseeing the A$300 million Dockalnds stadium in Victoria. The company will now focus on possible expansion in the Asian property market and is considering selling its manageent rights of the Melbourne Casino, valued at A$200 million, to Crown Ltd. Page 17.

Blueberry Farms of Australia Ltd yesterday warned its full-year 1997 profit would fall significantly below expectations primarily because of declining production levels at its older blueberry plantings. The news continues the company's poor record which began with an oversubscribed float in 1995 and a 1996 net profit which came in at only half of the prospectus forecast due to storm-blighted crops. Page 18.

Major ratings agencies have responded with caution to the detailed plan of the Australis and Foxtel merger unveiled last Friday. In addition trading in Australis shares has been suspended to allow investors time to fully consider the merger's impact. Pag 18

Mining company MIM Holdings Ltd was expected to register a net profit of between A$5 million and A$15 million for the 1996-97 year, however these forecasts are likely to be upgraded. The company has increased copper anode production for the year to 163,35 tonnes, with Wilson HTM research director Phil Hutchings describing the production figures as very positive. Page 18.

Matrix Telecommunications Ltd said yesterday it planned to raise A$48.6 million through a 1-for-2 renounceable rights issued priced at 80 cents a share. The rights issue will be fully underwritten by PBL marketing Pty Ltd, Hellman and Friedman Asia Pacifi III BV and investment group Innerhadden Ltd. Page 19
THE AUSTRALIAN

The West Australian State Government yesterday agreed to postpone the introduction of a gold royalty. The move will cost the State Government A$18 million in revenue this financial year and comes after intense pressure from the gold industry who argued tat on account to recent gold price fluctuations the new tax was not justified. Page 21.

Industry analysts say BHP will sell three of its Queensland mines as part of its review of its non-profitable coal assets. BHP has denied the rumours but is believed to have approached possible joint venture partners in an attempt to sell the Blackwater and Moura mines and the new South Walker Creek project. Page 21.

Australian mining companies Quantum Resources and Astro Mining are set to finalise the purchase of two diamond mines in China. The Wafangdian mine in Liaoning province produces 50 per cent of China's annual diamond production. The companies are owned by mining magnate Joseph Gutnick. Page 23.

Oil and gas company Santos has recorded a 4 per cent growth in second-quarter profits to A$194.9 million. The result has increased overall profit for the first half of 1997 to A$376.2 million and has been credited to rising production levels and sales reenue. Page 23.

The Victorian State Government has negotiated an A$150 million information technology financing and asset management contract with Macquarie Bank and Computer fleet Management. Macquarie Bank Corporate Financing and Leasing executive director Russell Lesie forecasts the deal will cut the Victorian Government's information technology costs by 10 per cent. Page 24.

Ratings agencies Moody's Investors Services and Standard & Poor's have assigned an AAA rating to St George for its A$4500 million mortgage-backed bond issue. The bonds issue will be conducted under the Crusade Trust and will be used to buy residential motgage loans. Page 25.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Impending rationalisation within the Australian radio industry and the prospect of large US players seeking an acquisition to gain market entry has fuelled speculation that Reg Grundy's RG Capital Radio will sell its 10 stations for over A$120 million. Pge 23.

With interest rates in Australia at their lowest levels in 25 years, small investors have flocked to put their money in cash management trusts. Investors recieve less financial returns than from the stock market, however the influx of investments into cash management funds have grown 118 per cent over the past two years. Page 23.

New figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistic show the dwelling units approved in New South Wales for semi-detached homes, townhouses or flats have risen from 25 per cent to over 50 per cent in the past 12 years. The trend is expected to adversely affect construction and building firms in the State. Page 25

Allegations by the Colorado Limited Gaming Commission relating to the influence and control of Australian company Aristocrat Leisure by unsuitable parties has prompted the company to file documents suggesting failure to follow due process. Page 25.

The Victorian Supreme Court in Australia has adjourned the Estate Mortgage case for six weeks pending negotiations between the litigants to reach an out-of-court settlement. Unitholders of the defunct Estate Mortgage trusts are expected to vote on a settlement by Burns Philp. Page 26

Australian mining company Dominion Mining has reached a A$630 million agreement with South Korea's Daewoo Corporation to develop nickel deposits at the Yakabindie project in Western Australian. Page 26
THE AGE

Telstra yesterday unveiled plans to move into the global telecommunications market through an agreement with giant international telecommunications company World Partners. In a memorandum of understanding signed between the two groups Telstra is free to negotiate an equity holding in World Partners. Page B1.

Metals and plumbing company GE Crane Holdings has overcome a depressed building sector market to record a net profit of A$28.9 million. The figures represent a 41 per cent increase on the previous year's net profit of A$20.3 million. Page B1.

The Austrim Group yesterday offered a A$208 million renounceable rights issue. The move is seen as preparation by the company for further acquisition plans and follows the announcement of a net profit for the 1996-97 year of A$21.9 million. Page B1.

Two international rail groups are believed to have made bids for the loss making rail group Australian National. One group consists of New Zealand's TranzRail, the US-based Wisconsin Central and the transport arm of French utilities giant CGE with the oter being led by US rail company Genesee and Wyoming. Page B2.
